snippet: Cheaper and easier than drones for doing surveillance, enormous helium balloons with cameras on board get mixed reviews from Afghans.
abstract: Surveillance balloons have become part of a widening network of devices in Afghanistan that allow American and Afghan commanders to watch more places where Americans are fighting; Afghans are split in their feeling about the surveillance, with some people hardly noticing the intrusion while others describe a growing sense of oppression.

byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg and Taimoor Shah contributed reporting from Kandahar, Afghanistan, and Afghan employees of The New York Times from Kunar, Nangarhar, Kunduz and Helmand Provinces.

lead_paragraph: Cheaper and easier than drones for doing surveillance, enormous helium balloons with cameras on board get mixed reviews from Afghans.
